subject: Re: [junit] Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... Comments that merely describe how the code does things is waste. The code already says that. These are the comments that a vast majority of programmers
messageBody:
Jim Dixon wrote:

> On Wed, 17 Sep 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> > > Never, ever, ever? I can see why the System.out.println() is
> > > redundant here, since the assertEquals will provide the actual
> > > length of the vector on failure. But generally, when and where
> > > are diagnostic messages in tests appropriate? Do you have a problem
> > > with System.out.println() or diagnostic messages in tests in general?
> >
> > They're like comments. Comments are not executable and cannot fail if
> > they are wrong, so they are waste.
>
> So code should never be commented?? This makes no sense.

Comments that merely describe how the code does things is waste. The
code already says that. These are the comments that a vast majority of
programmers insist on writing, largely because someone taught them to do
so in school.

Comments of the type "We had to do this silly thing because...."
actually communicate something.

> > Diagnostic messages are not
> > assertions and cannot fail if they are wrong, so they are waste.
>
> It is trivially easy to put diagnostic messages inside an if -- you
> see them if something of interest occurs.

Waste is waste. Large amounts of waste often build themselves up from a
large number of small amounts of waste.

> > Make an
> > assertion instead.
>
> Usually. But sometimes what you want is a soft assertion -- if the
> condition doesn't hold, let me know, but keep on going. And JUnit
> doesn't support that approach.

No surprise there: JUnit is not a logging tool.

I can't think of the last time I was interested in finding an unexpected
event that did not cause me to want the application to stop so that I
could fix it. Of course, I am talking about while programming, and not
while in production.
